Sulfur poisoning is an intractable challenge for NH3-SCR catalyst. In this issue, the immanent reasons for MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst deactivation resulting from SO2 were elaborated by catalytic activity evaluation, BET, XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and in-situ DRIFTS analysis. Results showed that MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst followed E-R reaction mechanism and performed 100 % NO conversion at 175 °C, whereas its sulfur resistance was unsatisfactory and the deactivation degree became more severe with SO2 concentration increasing. SO2 reacted with NH3 to generate (NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4 deposits, blocking catalyst pores and covering active sites. SO2 also interacted with MnOx-CeO2 active components to form MnSO4 and Ce2(SO4)3, which restricted the electron transfers of Mn4+/Mnn+ and Ce3+/Ce4+. Besides, the newly formed sulfur-containing acidic sites also competed with the original active sites for NH3 adsorption, thereby hindering the SCR reaction. Physical purging could not realize regeneration of SO2-poisoning catalyst, but hyperthermic treatment was an efficient solution. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MnOx-CeO2 catalyst Ti-bearing blast furnace slag NH3-SCR SO2 poisoning mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ti-bearing blast furnace slag is a byproduct of vanadium-titanium magnetite smelting in a blast furnace. Its main components include TiO2, SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, CaO, FeOx (total content > 98 wt.%), and a small number of other substances. According to the TiO2 content in the slag, high-titanium slag (>16 % TiO2), medium-titanium slag (10 %−16 % TiO2), and low-titanium slag (<10 % TiO2) can be distinguished. Titanium resources for medium- and high-titanium slag is recycled using wet titanium extraction technology, and a small amount of low-titanium slag is utilized as an additive in construction materials, but a lot of titanium slag still largely accumulates in yards, seriously leading to environmental pollution and significant resource waste [1–4]. Therefore, the resource utilization of Ti-bearing blast furnace slag, especially low-titanium slag, has become a research hotspot. Selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) is the main technique for removing NOx, with the catalyst being the core, especially low-temperature SCR catalysts, which have been a recent research focus [5]. SCR catalysts mainly consist of active components, active promoters and carriers. Many transition metal oxides, such as V2O5, MnOx, CuO, Fe2O3, SnO2, NiO, etc., exhibit good SCR activity in the low-temperature range and can be used as active components for low-temperature denitration catalysts [6–9]. Yang et al. [10] respectively loaded Mn, Ce, V and Fe on the biomass char carrier and then compared their low-temperature denitration activity, finding that the SCR performance followed an increasing sequence of Mn > Ce > V > Fe. Jiang et al. [11] prepared the low-temperature catalysts with TiO2 as the support by sol-gel method, and their denitrification activities followed the order of Mn/TiO2 > Fe/TiO2 > Cu/TiO2∼Cr/TiO2 > Ni/TiO2. MnOx easily involves in electron conversions during SCR reactions, thereby promoting the denitrification process and performing excellent low-temperature NO conversion and N2 selectivity, making it the ideal active component of low-temperature SCR catalysts [10–12]. CeO2 has excellent oxygen storage capacity and exhibits good sulfur and water resistance at low temperatures, which is broadly used as an active promoter for low-temperature SCR catalysts. Jin et al. [13] added CeO2 to MnO2/TiO2 catalyst to prepare MnO2-CeO2/TiO2 catalyst using sol-gel method. The catalytic activity reached more than 95 % at 150 °C, and the addition of Ce reduced the generation of ammonium sulfate and improved the resistance to sulfur poisoning. Ren et al. [14] investigated the role of Ce in improving the properties of Mn/ASC catalyst at low-temperature, and found that Ce doping raised the rates of Mn4+/Mnn+ electron transfers, improved the amount of weak and strong acid sites, increased oxygen vacancies and accelerated the transitions from molecular oxygen to reactive oxygen species, consequently enhancing the NO oxidation activity and denitrification efficiency. Overall, Ce addition not only greatly enhances the dispersion of Mn on the catalyst surface, but also provides oxygen for the reacted MnOx, thereby restoring the catalytic performance [13–15]. The carrier mainly acting as a support of the catalyst, increases the effective catalytic reaction surface, provides suitable pore structure and improves the thermal stability and resistance to poisoning, thus laying the solid foundation for preparing low-temperature SCR catalysts. Commonly used carriers for low-temperature catalysts mainly include activated carbon, TiO2, Al2O3, diatomaceous earth, and zeolite (mainly composed of SiO2) [16–19]. Since Ti-bearing blast furnace slag mainly consists of TiO2, SiO2, Al2O3, CaO, it can be regarded as a mixed carrier for preparing excellent catalysts and achieving the resource utilization of titanium slag. Previously, the authors have successfully prepared an MnOx-CeO2/low-titanium blast furnace slag catalyst, which exerted excellent SCR activity with NO removal rate of over 90 % at 200 °C [20]. However, these catalysts inevitably come into contact with toxic substances (e.g., dust, acidic gases, alkali metals/alkaline earth metals, heavy metals, etc.) during the process of removing NOx from industry flue gas, thus leading to catalyst poisoning and deactivation. Especially, the acidic gas SO2 is one of the main contributors. Previous studies have conducted on the sulfur poisoning mechanism of Mn-based catalysts and the enhancement of sulfur resistance with Ce component for Mn-based catalysts [13,14,21–23]. However, the sulfur poisoning of MnOx-CeO2 based catalysts prepared with low-titanium blast furnace slag as a mixed carrier has not been symmetrically clarified. Only understanding the influence of SO2 gases on the denitrification performance of MnOx-CeO2/low-titanium blast furnace slag SCR catalyst and clarifying its sulfur poisoning mechanism, can catalytic performance of this catalyst be further optimized and strategies for enhancing the sulfur resistance capacity of the catalyst be proposed, as well as theoretical support be provided for the industrial application of the MnOx-CeO2/low-titanium blast furnace slag catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The authors have successfully prepared MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst referring our previous research (denoted as MC) [20]. The catalyst was placed in a gas-solid reaction fixed-bed experimental system (as shown in Fig. 1 ) and exposed to a certain concentration of SO2 at a constant temperature of 225 °C for 18 h to simulate sulfur poisoning. SO2-poisoned catalyst was labeled as MCSO-x, where x represents the concentration of SO2 (50, 100, and 200 ppm). 2.2 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic performance evaluation was conducted in the fixed bed reactor with the experimental conditions: 500 ppm NO, 11 % O2, 50/100/200 ppm SO2 (when used), with N2 as the balance gas. The total gas flow rate was 200 mL/min and GHSV of 24,000 h −1. The catalyst dosage was 0.4 g, and the testing temperature range was 75–300 °C. Catalytic activity was determined by NO conversion and N2 selectivity, calculated as Eq. (1) and Eq (2). (1) NO conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − [ NO ] Out [ NO ] In ) × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] out + [ N O 2 ] out [ NO ] in + [ N H 3 ] in ) × 100 % 2.3 Catalyst characterization The BET surface area and pore structure parameters were calculated by N2 physisorption at 77 K using ASAP2020 analyzer. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were measured with a PANalytical X'Pert Powder diffractometer with scanning rate of 5 o/min in 2θ range of 10–90°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on Thermo ESCALAB250Xi with binding energy referenced to C1s at 284.6 eV. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was carried out on an AutoChem II2920 Micromeritics Instrument. Sample (100 mg) was set in one arm of a U-shaped quartz tube, pretreated in He (50 mL/min) for 1 h at 400 °C and then cooled down to 50 °C. 5 % NH3 in He (50 mL/min) was used for adsorption (1 h) and then purged in He until the TCD signal was stabilized. Finally, the sample was heated up to 500 °C (10 °C/min) under a fow of He (50 mL/min) to record the NH3 TCD signal. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurement was performed on an Autochem-II adsorption instrument. Each catalyst (200 mg) was pretreated using He (50 mL/min) for 1 h at 300 °C and then cooled to 30 °C. Each sample was later heated to 800 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of hydrogen gas to record H2 TPR signal. In-situ DRIFTS were recorded on a ThermoFisher Nicolet iS50 spectrometer under different atmosphere conditions. The detection wavelength range was 700–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 32 accumulations of scans. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of MnO x -CeO2/ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst 3.1.1 BET analysis To investigate the effect of SO2 on catalyst pore structure, N2 physical adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted on MC, MCSO-50, MCSO-100, and MCSO-200 catalysts, results were shown in Table 1 . The BET surface area of MC catalyst was 264.3 m2/g, ensuring sufficient active sites and excellent denitrification activity. After SO2 poisoning, the surface area gradually decreased with SO2 concentration increasing. This was mainly because NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 species generated by reaction of SO2 and NH3 (confirmed in Figs. 4(d), 5, 6 and 7), which deposited on catalyst surface, block catalyst surface pores and cause specific surface area decrease. The similar phenomenon also can be found in the relevant literature [24]. The pore volume showed an increasing and then decreasing trend, with no significant changes in pore size. The pore volume of the fresh MC catalyst was 0.05 cm3/g. When 50 ppm SO2 was introduced, it was found that the pore volume slightly increased to 0.11 cm3/g, and then gradually decreased with increasing SO2 concentration (the pore volume of MCSO-200 catalyst decreased to 0.05 cm3/g). Combined with XPS and in-situ DRIFTS results, it can be inferred that due to the introduction of SO2, ammonium sulfate/bisulfate species were formed on the poisoned MCSO-50 catalyst, resulting in the formation of some new pore structures on its surface, which in turn lead to a slight increase in the pore volume of the catalyst. However, as the poisoning concentration of SO2 increased, more sulfate species formed on the catalyst surface, which would inevitably cause more severe clogging of the pores and resulted in a continuous decrease in the specific surface area. Therefore, formation of new pore structure, caused by the deposition of NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 species, was responsible for this phenomenon. It can be proved in Fig. 2 , which displayed N2 physical adsorption-desorption curves of the catalysts. Although all the curves belonged to type IV isotherm (mesoporous material) with an H1 hysteresis loop (a typical cylindrical pore geometry), the desorption curves of MCSO-50 catalysts changed obviously, indicationg that the pore structure of the catalyst has undergone significant changes after the passage of 50 ppm SO2. However, when higher concentrations of SO2 were passed through (100 ppm, 200 ppm), the newly formed pore structure on the surface was destroyed and blocked by the generated sulfate or bisulfate, resulting in a small change in the adsorption-desorption curves. Based on the relevant literatures [25,26], conclusions can be drawn that these sulfate or bisulfates species do not decompose at low temperature and ultimately block the active sites of MC catalyst, consequently resulting in catalyst deactivation and then slowing down the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.1.2 XRD analysis As shown in Fig. 3 , diffraction peaks of MnO2 (JCPDS NO. 01–0799) and CeO2 (JCPDS NO. 01–0800) were detected on the MC catalyst, indicating that part of active components (manganese and cerium oxides) crystallized during catalyst preparation process. After treating with different concentrations of SO2, the phase composition slightly changed. For MCSO-50 catalyst, the intensity of CeO2 and MnO2 diffraction peaks at 32.1° and 56.1° enhanced, implying that SO2 further promoted crystallization of CeO2 and MnO2. Generally, active components in the highly dispersed or amorphous forms are more favorable for improving catalytic properties, but the crystallization from is disadvantageous for SCR reactions which was a key contributor to deactivate SCR catalysts. It was also worth noting that the other diffraction peaks intensities associated with MnO2 and CeO2 on the MCSO-50 catalyst decreased, speculating that the active components partly reacted with SO2 (sulfation). Moreover, the peaks intensity at 32.1° and 45° significantly decreased on MCSO-100 and MCSO-200 catalysts, and the diffraction peak of MnO2 at 42.1° even disappeared, which indicated that high concentrations of SO2 would cause more severe sulfation of MnOx-CeO2. This inference could be confirmed by the following characterization results (XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, TG), which was also reported in relevant literature [37]. This behavior can seriously destroy acidic sites provided by these active components, so that the NH3 adsorption on effective active sites could be limited, while these adsorbed species showed low reactivity and did not well participate in SCR reaction (proved by in-situ DRIFTS results). 3.1.3 XPS analysis The effect of SO2 on element chemical valences was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the results were presented in Fig. 4 and Table 2 . The Ce 3d XPS spectrum was shown in Fig. 4 (a), and the spin-orbit splitting peaks of Ce 3d3/2 (875∼897 eV) and Ce 3d5/2 (897∼909 eV) were obtained after peak fitting. The peaks at 886.5 (±0.2) eV and 881.9 (±0.2) eV were attributed to Ce3+, while other peaks were attributed to Ce4+ [27,28]. After poisoned by SO2 with different concentrations, all the binding energies noticeably shifted to lower position, except for Ce4+ peak at 916.6 eV. This result confirmed the speculation that reactions between SO2 and CeO2 occurred, and the original electron structure of CeO2 was broken. In addition, although the ratio of Ce3+/Cen+ on the surface of MCSO-50 and MCSO-100 samples increased compared to MC catalyst, the signal intensity significantly decreased. This meant that the detected total Cen+ content on the surface of SO2-poisoned catalyst still reduced. It was because the formation of ammonium sulfates covered CeOx components on the catalyst surface. From the Mn 2p XPS spectra in Fig. 4(b), it can be seen that MnOx on the catalyst surface mainly existed in three states (Mn2+, Mn3+, Mn4+), corresponding to binding energies of 641.2∼641.5 eV, 642.7∼643.5 eV and 644.7∼647.0 eV [29–31]. Similar to the Ce 3d results, Mn 2p peak intensity of MCSO-50 and MCSO-100 catalysts decreased due to the formation of ammonium sulfates species. For MCSO-200 catalyst, the interactions between MnOx and SO2, generating manganese sulfate substance slowed down the electron transfers of Mn4+/Mn3+, consequently resulting in serious catalyst deactivation. Fig. 4(c) showed the O 1 s XPS spectra of MC and SO2-poisoned catalyst. The peak at binding energy of 529.1–530.5 eV was attributed to lattice oxygen (Oβ), and the peak at binding energy of 531.1–533.2 eV was attributed to surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) [27]. It can be seen that the relative content of chemisorbed oxygen on the poisoned catalyst surface was higher than that on the fresh catalyst. This was related to the oxidizing ability of SO2. However, excessive surface chemisorbed oxygen also leads to occurrence of side reactions during NH3-SCR process, such as the oxidation of ammonia, which is harmful to the catalyst denitration. The peak fitting results of S 2p spectrum of fresh MC and SO2-poisoned catalyst were shown in Fig. 4(d), which showed a combination of S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 spectra. The peak at approximately 165.0 eV was assigned to metal sulfide and sulphide [32], aother peak at around 169.1 eV was ascribed to S4+ in the adsorption form of SO2 or aggregated surface sulfites [33]. The results revealed that a variety of S-containing species, including surface sulfites, sulfates and metal sulfides, were generated and co-existed on the SO2-deactivated catalysts surface, which can be attributed to the interaction between SO2 and MnOx-CeO2 or NH3 on the catalyst during SCR process. In order to further verify the formation of sulfate/ammonium salts on SO2 poisoning catalyst, thermogravimetric (TG) test was conducted on the poisoned catalyst, and the results were shown in Fig. 5 . According to the variation of TG-DTG-DSC curves, the whole process can be divided into four stages. During the heating process, an obvious weight loss peak (stage A) appeared at the beginning of the catalyst. This part mainly removed the crystal water inside the catalyst and the adsorbed water on the surface. With the increase of temperature, the sample continuously lost weight between 200 °C and 500 °C, which was mainly due to the decomposition of (NH4)2SO4 or NH4HSO4, but its DTG curve changed steadily, indicating that the decomposition rate remained stable at this stage. In stage C, weight loss continued and a new weight loss peak of DSC appeared, which was mainly related to the decomposition of Mn(SO4)2 or Ce2(SO4)3. Above 700 °C belonged to stage D, where the weight loss was slight, but the DSC changed greatly, which was speculated to be caused by the decomposition of MnSO4 [34–36]. Therefore, detailed reaction processes between SO2 and catalyst could be described as following. (3) SO2(g) → SO2(ads) (4) SO2(ads) + 4NH3(ads) + O2 + H2O → 2(NH4)2SO4/NH4HSO4 (5) SO2(ads) + MnO2/CeO2 + O2 → MnSO4/Ce2(SO4)3 (6) SO2(ads) + O2− → SO4 2− (7) SO2(ads) + -O-H → -SO3H− 3.1.4 NH3-TPD and H2-TPR analysis NH3 adsorption ability on acidic sites is a key indicator for NH3-SCR catalyst. Fig. 6 showed the NH3-TPD curves and corresponding integrated areas of NH3-desorption peaks of MC and SO2-poisoned catalysts. The sharp desorption peak (Peak I) at around 107 °C of MC catalyst was corresponded to NH3 adsorption (NH4 +) on weak acidic sites (Brønsted acid sites), The broad desorption peak (Peak II) between 300 and 550 °C was corresponded to NH3 adsorption (coordinated NH3) on strong acidic sites (Lewis acid sites) [37]. Generally, integrated area of the desorption peaks is positively correlated with the number of acidic sites on catalyst surface. Therefore, in the case of MC catalyst, the number of Brønsted acid sites was approximately three times as many as Lewis acid sites, suggesting that the Brønsted acid sites on MC catalyst played a dominant role in NH3-SCR reactions. After SO2 poisoning, it was obvious that the desorption peak corresponding to Brønsted acidic sites was narrowed with lower integrated area of peak I, whereas the peak belonging to Lewis acidic sites was strengthened with larger integrated area of peak II. According to the above XPS analysis, a variety of S-containing species (surface sulfites, sulphide and metal sulfide) were generated and co-existed on the surface of SO2-poisoned catalyst. Therefore, conclusion can be drawn that SO2 poisoning was easier to destroy Brønsted acidic sites of fresh MC catalyst, and the key reasons were as follows: (1) the deposition of ammonium sulfates, as the competitive Lewis acidic sites, prevented the original active sites exposure; (2) the generation of metal sulfates (MnSO4 and Ce2(SO4)3) by the interaction between MnOx-CeO2 and SO2 destroyed the Brønsted acidic sites for NH3 adsorption. It was also worth noting that the total amount of NH3 adsorption on SO2-poisoned catalyst increased instead, and the obvious change of Lewis acid sites contributed for this result. The sulfate ions (SO4 2−) generating from oxidation of SO2 on catalyst surface exhibited similar characteristics with strong acidic site, but the adsorbed ammonia on this acidic site has weak function on SCR denitration reaction. Particularly, the total amount of NH3 adsorption on MCSO-200 slightly declined compared with other poisoned catalysts. Combined with the analysis of Table 1, it can speculate that a large amount of sulfate species was deposited on MCSO-200 catalyst, which seriously blocked acid sites and thus decreased the total acidity. Combined with the catalytic outcome of MC catalyst system (Fig. 9(a)), conclusion can be drawn that its SCR activity was mainly associated with effective Brønsted acid sites, and efficient catalytic reactions were difficult to proceed on the inactive Lewis sites formed by SO2 poisoning. H2-TPR experiment can evaluate the catalyst redox ability, and the results were presented in Fig. 7 . The onset reduction temperature of MC catalyst was 190 °C, and its H2-TPR curve could be divided into three reduction peaks. The peak at 374 °C was attributed to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3, the peak at 438 °C was originated from the reduction of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, Mn3O4 to MnO, and CeO2 reduction [38]. The reduction peak observed at ∼563 °C could be ascribed to functional groups reduction of Ti-Si-Al support [39]. After SO2 poisoning, the catalyst onset reduction temperature increased, and the reduction temperature of manganese and cerium oxides shifted to higher region. This indicated that the redox ability of manganese and cerium oxides in the poisoned catalyst was restrained, and thus the cycle of SCR reaction was retarded. It was worth noting that distinguished from fresh MC catalyst, an obvious H2 consumption peak at around 580 °C appeared on these sulfur-poisoned catalysts, which abundantly implied that the various sulfur-bearing species (sulfites/sulfates, sulphide and metal sulfide) were significantly formed in the catalytic redox cycle. This phenomenon is similar to that observed in the literature [40]. Combined with all analysis in previous sections, it can comfirm that NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 species deposited and adhered on MnOx-CeO2 components on the catalyst surface, inhibiting their reduction reactions. Moreover, the sulfation made manganese and cerium oxides more difficult to be reduced. Overall, the introduction of SO2 inhibited the redox cycle of MnOx-CeO2 active components, resulting in a significant decrease in the catalytic activity for denitration. 3.1.5 In-situ drifts analysis (1) Adsorption of SO2+O2 In order to investigate the adsorption behavior of SO2 on catalyst surface, in-situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted. The MC catalyst was pre-treated at 225 °C under N2 purging for 30 min to collect the background. Then, the gas was switched to a mixture of 200 ppm SO2 and 10 vol.% O2 (N2 as carrier gas), and the sample was continuously exposed for 40 min. The real-time infrared spectra of SO2 adsorption on MC catalyst were shown in Fig. 8 (a). After introducing SO2, stretching vibration of bulk sulfates appeared at 1300 cm−1, while S=O vibration of sulfate species appeared at 1380 cm−1. The peak at 1061 cm−1 was related to the stretching vibration of ammonium sulfate or sulfate [39,41]. Above results confirmed our aforementioned inferences that SO2 adsorbed on catalyst surface and reacted with MnOx-CeO2 active components or the adsorbed NH3, generating ammonium sulfate (NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4) or other sulfate substances (Ce2(SO4)3 and MnSO4), thereby suppressing the SCR reactions. (2) Adsorption of SO2+O2 followed by NH3 The MC catalyst was pre-treated at 225 °C under N2 protection for 30 min to collect the background. Then, the gas was switched to a mixture of 200 ppm SO2 and 10 vol.% O2 (N2 as carrier gas) and continuously adsorbed for 40 min. After that, N2 purging was conducted for 30 min to remove physically adsorbed SO2 on the catalyst surface. Then, 1000 ppm NH3 was introduced and continuously adsorbed for 60 min. The total gas flow rate was 50 mL/min. The collected infrared spectra were shown in Fig. 8(b). In addition, under the same pre-treatment conditions, 1000 ppm NH3 (N2 as carrier gas) was solely introduced to the MC catalyst and continuously adsorbed for 60 min as a reference sample. The collected infrared spectra were shown in Fig. 8(c). In Fig. 8(b), it can be seen that after SO2 pretreatment, the peak intensity at 1061 cm−1, attributing to ammonium sulfate or sulfate species, enhanced with NH3 introducing, which confirmed the reactions between the adsorbed SO2 and NH3. Besides, after NH3 introduction, the absorbed peak at 3268 cm−1 and 1514 cm−1 (N-H stretching modes and symmetric bending vibrations of N-H bonds in coordinated NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites) gradually appeared within 10 min, whereas this peak center gradually shifted to 1432 cm−1 (asymmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites) and peak intensity became more obvious at 60 min. Differently, only the NH3 adsorbed peak at 1432 cm−1 occurred on fresh MC catalyst after solely NH3 gases introduced. The phenomenon suggested that the formed ammonium sulfate or sulfate species also provided acidic sites for the adsorption of gaseous NH3 molecule. Nevertheless, combined with the obvious difference in SCR activities of MC catalyst before and after SO2 poisoning, it can conclude that there was competitive adsorption of NH3 between MnOx-CeO2 components and the generated ammonium sulfate/sulfate species. The latter didn't participate in SCR reaction and thus the poisoned catalyst performed low catalytic performance. (3) Adsorption of NH3 followed by NO+O2 In order to clarify the adsorption and denitration processes on the surfaces of MC and MCSO-200 catalyst, after NH3 adsorption saturation (60 min), the catalysts were purged with N2 for 30 min to remove the residual NH3. Then, NO+O2 was introduced into the in-situ reaction cell, and the spectra were recorded as a function of time, as shown in Fig. 8(d) and 8(e). In Fig. 8(d), it can be seen that after 60 min adsorption of NH3, the peak at 3268 cm−1 on MC catalyst was caused by the symmetric stretching vibration of N-H bond in the coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites. In addition, the peak at 1432 and 1706 cm−1 were mainly due to adsorbed NH4 + on Brønsted acid sites. After the introduction of NO+O2, ammonia adsorption bands disappeared within 20 min, and almost no NOx species appeared throughout the process. However, in the poisoned MCSO-200 catalyst, NH4 + species at 1706 cm−1 was not detected and the peak at 1432 cm−1 was still obvious until 20 min. It suggested that the active sites (activate adsorbed NH3 into NH4 +) were destroyed by sulfur, and thus the adsorbed-NH3 species on the fresh MC and poisoned MCSO-200 catalysts showed the different reactivities in NO reduction. SO2 mainly affected the Brønsted acid sites (1432 and 1706 cm−1), which was consistent with the NH3-TPD results. (4) Adsorption of NO+O2 followed by NH3 After saturation adsorption of NO+O2 on MC and MCSO-200 catalysts (60 min), N2 purging was performed for 30 min to remove the residual NO+O2. Then, NH3 was introduced into the in-situ reaction cell, and the spectra were recorded as a function of time, as shown in Fig. 8(f) and 8(g). The results showed that as NO+O2 introducing, no peaks related to adsorbed NOx species were observed, meaning that NO gases were difficult to be absorbed on the series of MC catalysts. Combined with Fig. 8(d) and 8(f), we can conclude that only gaseous NH3 were inclined to adsorbed on acid sites of the catalysts and then directly react with gaseous NO, which implied that the MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst followed Eley-Rideal (E-R) reaction mechanism. SO2 poisoning also did not change E-R reaction mechanism of the catalyst, but significantly inhibited the behaviors of NH3 adsorption and activation. In conclusion, SO2 poisoning hindered effective NH3 adsorption on the active components (MnOx-CeO2) through generating metal sulfates/ammonium sulfate salts deposited on catalyst surface. More inactive adsorbed-NH3 species existed on these S-containing sites and then slowed down the following NO reduction, which consequently resulted in a marked decline of catalyst SCR performance. 3.1.6 Chapter summary In this Section 3.1, a series of characterization tests were carried out to clarify the SO2 poisoning mechanism on the MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag (MC) catalyst. Results revealed that SO2 poisoning could lead to the formation of a variety of S-containing species (e.g., surface sulfites, sulfates and metal sulfides., etc.) on the MC catalysts surface (Figs. 4 and 5). For one thing, these ammonium (bi)sulfates/sulfates species were formed in the catalytic redox cycle, thus affecting the Mnn+/Cen+ electron conversion (Fig. 7). For another thing, these by-products seriously damaged active Lewis acid sites provided by Mn-Ce components, and even replenished inactive Brønsted acid sites from sulfate ions (SO4 2−) oxidized by SO2 gases (Fig. 6). Noted that more inactive adsorbed-NH3 species existed on these S-containing sites and then slowed down the following NO reduction (Fig. 8), which consequently resulted in a marked decline of SCR performance (Fig. 9 ). 3.2 Effect of SO2 on catalytic activities of MnO x -CeO2/ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst SO2 is a typical harmful component in metallurgical sintering and coking, and waste incineration flue gas for deactivating denitrification catalyst. Experiments concerning the effect of SO2 on catalytic activities of MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst were carried out under different concentrations of SO2 atmosphere, as shown in Fig. 9(a). In the stage of low-temperature (< 200 °C), NO conversion of MC catalyst increased rapidly with temperature rising, performing 100 % efficiency started from 200 °C. The results showed that MC catalyst had excellent denitrification performance. However, after MC catalyst exposing to SO2 atmosphere, its catalytic activity was seriously suppressed. NO conversion of MCSO-200 catalyst was only 30 % at 200 °C, and the main reasons can be summarized as follows. NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4, generating from the reaction between SO2 and NH3, deposited on catalyst surface, thus obstructing the catalyst surface pores and covering the active sites on the catalyst surface, intercepting the contact between reaction gases and active components, which resulted in the serious decline in catalyst activity. In addition, reactions between the active components and adsorbed SO2 formed metal sulfates (MnSO4 and Ce2(SO4)3), which declined the active sites for reaction gases adsorption and further inhibited the SCR denitrification reaction. It was worth noting that NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 species depositing on catalyst surface gradually decomposed with the reaction temperature increasing from 100 °C to 300 °C. The behaviors promoted re-exposure of the active sites and then denitrification activity of the catalyst gradually recovered to the level before poisoning. For the MCSO-200 catalyst, its activity was still difficult to recover to the original value at 300 °C, indicating that when the MC catalyst was exposed to a high concentration of SO2 atmosphere, its active components and internal structure have undergone irreversible damage. As presented in Fig. 9(b), fresh MC catalyst showed excellent N2 selectivity (more than 80 %) at low temperature (< 175 °C), suggesting that the effective SCR reaction normally occurred on the MC catalyst (Eqs. (6), (7) and (8)). However, with temperature continually increasing, the amount of N2O obviously increased due to NH3 oxidation (Eq. (9), (10) and (11)) arising from manganese-cerium oxides at high temperatures (> 200 C), which has been previously mentioned in the literature [42]. After SO2 poisoning, the N2 selectivity of all catalysts maintained more than 90 %, accompanied with the low concentration of N2O (< 35 ppm). This result indicated that the active components (MnOx-CeO2) in SO2-poisoned catalysts were seriously deactivated, and thus the SCR reactions and sides reactions were greatly restrained. Additionally, Fig. 9(c) displayed outlet concentrations of NH3 and NO2 during this SCR process. Results implied that the outlet NH3 amount gradually declined with reaction temperature rising, and the fresh MC catalyst showed the most obviously. The NO2 content was less than 10 ppm on fresh MC and all poisoned catalysts. 4NH3 + 4NO + O2 → 4N2 + 6H2O (6) 2NO2 + 4NH3 + O2 → 3N2 + 6H2O (7) NO2 + NO + 2NH3 → 2N2 + 3H2O (8) 4NO + 3O2 + 4NH3 → 4N2O + 6H2O (9) 2NH3 + O2 → N2O + 3H2O (10) 4NH3 + 5O2 → 4NO + 6H2O (11) Fig. 9(d) showed the curve of denitrification activities under different concentrations of SO2 atmosphere over time (constant temperature at 225 °C). When the MC catalyst was continuously exposed to different concentrations of SO2 environment, its denitrification activity gradually decreased. When the SO2 gas was turned off, the denitrification activity of the catalyst did not recover. Thus, conclusion can be drawn that physical purging could not realize catalyst regeneration from sulfur poisoning, but hyperthermic treatment was an effective solution. Fig. 9(e) presented the outlet concentrations of main by-products (N2O and NO2) on MC catalyst after 200 ppm SO2 introduction at 225 °C within 1040 min. Before SO2 introduction, the N2O concentration of MC catalyst gradually increased and remained at nearly 100 ppm. The main reason was that the SCR reactions and NH3 oxidation occurred on the catalyst while the reaction rates gradually increased with the temperature rising. After 200 ppm SO2 purge, the outlet N2O concentration dropped to nearly 25 ppm and then stayed at this level. These results were well accordance with the above discussions, indicating SO2 poisoning could deactivate MnOx-CeO2 ingredients, consequently slowing down the SCR reactions and NH3 oxidation. During denitrification process, SO2 and water exist in the flue gas at the same time, so the activity of anti-sulfur and anti-water at 225 °C was tested and result was shown in Fig. 9(f). When 5 vol.% water vapor was added separately, the catalytic activity of MC catalyst basically unchanged and remained stable at about 80 %. However, after the introduction of 200 ppm SO2, its activity was significantly decreased, and the NO conversion stabilized at about 30 %. The toxic effect of SO2 was more obvious in the presence of water than in the MC fresh catalyst (39.2 %) which was injected with SO2 alone. Refer to relevant literature [43], it can be inferred that this is mainly due to the reaction of SO2 with H2O to form sulfite (H2SO3), and further oxidation with O2 to form sulfate at high temperature, which aggravates the sulfation of mangano-cerium oxide by SO2. After the removal of SO2, the activity of MC catalyst recovered to 50 %, and after the removal of H2O, the activity further recovered to about 60 %. The above phenomenon showed that the toxic effect of water on MC catalyst was negligible, but when water and SO2 exist at the same time, the poisoning of the catalyst was seriously intensified. 4 Conclusions In this work, the effect of SO2 on MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalysts for NH3-SCR of NOx at low temperature was investigated by a series of characterizations. Based on the results, conclusions can be drawn as follows. (1) MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst followed E-R reaction mechanism. It showed excellent denitrification performance at low temperature, and the NO conversion was almost 100 % at 175 °C. However, its resistance to sulfur poisoning was unsatisfactory, and the catalyst deactivation degree became more serious with SO2 concentration increasing. (2) SO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface and reacted with gaseous NH3 to generate (NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4 deposits, blocking the catalyst pore structures and covering the active acid sites, resulting in the decrease of catalyst surface area and denitrification activity. (3) SO2 also could react with the catalyst active components to form metal sulfates (MnSO4 and Ce2(SO4)3), which limited the electron transfer process of Mn4+/Mnn+ and Ce3+/Ce4+, as well as promoted the crystallization of manganese and cerium oxides, thereby leading to catalyst deactivation. (4) SO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form new acidic sites, competing with the original active sites for NH3 adsorption, thereby hindering the SCR reaction. (5) For the SO2-poisoned catalyst, physical purging could not realize catalyst regeneration, but hyperthermic treatment was an efficient solution. coredata.dc:description: Sulfur poisoning is an intractable challenge for NH3-SCR catalyst. In this issue, the immanent reasons for MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst deactivation resulting from SO2 were elaborated by catalytic activity evaluation, BET, XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and in-situ DRIFTS analysis. Results showed that MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst followed E-R reaction mechanism and performed 100 % NO conversion at 175 °C, whereas its sulfur resistance was unsatisfactory and the deactivation degree became more severe with SO2 concentration increasing. SO2 reacted with NH3 to generate (NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4 deposits, blocking catalyst pores and covering active sites. SO2 also interacted with MnOx-CeO2 active components to form MnSO4 and Ce2(SO4)3, which restricted the electron transfers of Mn4+/Mnn+ and Ce3+/Ce4+. Besides, the newly formed sulfur-containing acidic sites also competed with the original active sites for NH3 adsorption, thereby hindering the SCR reaction. Physical purging could not realize regeneration of SO2-poisoning catalyst, but hyperthermic treatment was an efficient solution.
